channel.title: Anyone know the use of the process System Idle Process?
channel.description: All it seems to do is eat at my CPU usage and i cant end it, its only really come about recently so i dont know much about it or where it came from if anyone can enlighten me please do

item.title: Anyone know the use of the process System Idle Process?
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

I actually LMAO’ed at this.

However I’m going to lock this to prevent further flame. In future, read the name of the process, it’s quite self-explanatory.

Read full topic

item.title: Anyone know the use of the process System Idle Process?
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:6, topic:232891”][quote author=BloodRayne link=topic=307145.msg2456173#msg2456173 date=1222249295]

You are either a pro troll, or a complete fuckstick.

I do not think you’re qualified to say that.

gtfo.

System Idle Process has something to do with your RAM, and having quicker access to it, I think. Wikipedia doesn’t seem to agree though, but meh.

en.wikipedia.org

System Idle Process

In Windows NT operating systems, the System Idle Process contains one or more kernel threads which run when no other runnable thread can be scheduled on a CPU. In a multiprocessor system, there is one idle thread associated with each CPU core. For a system with hyperthreading enabled, there is an idle thread for each logical processor. The primary purpose of the idle process and its threads is to eliminate what would otherwise be a special case in the scheduler. Without the idle threads, there ...


[/quote]
You’re a fucking retard, it has absolutely nothing to do with your RAM.

It’s not actually eating your CPU, it’s showing the percentage of CPU time that is “Idle”. Technically it’s not even a real process.[/quote]
ok cool so i can just leave it there? thanks for the one post that was actually helpful

Read full topic
item.source: Anyone know the use of the process System Idle Process?

gtfo.

System Idle Process has something to do with your RAM, and having quicker access to it, I think. Wikipedia doesn’t seem to agree though, but meh.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_Idle_Process[/quote]
You’re a fucking retard, it has absolutely nothing to do with your RAM.

It’s not actually eating your CPU, it’s showing the percentage of CPU time that is “Idle”. Technically it’s not even a real process.
